body:
@dusenberrymw 
I believe right now get() returns a SystemML MatrixObject if dealing with a matrix. We should probably have it return a Matrix (very easy to do in a couple lines of code). However, perhaps we could do this in a separate followup JIRA/PR, along with adding a Matrix type to the Python API?
Thank you for reviewing @gweidner!

@gweidner Thank you for looking at this Glenn!

@mboehm7 Does the approach in the PR seem correct?
Can an Admin verify this patch?
@niketanpansare I've left additional comments from another full pass through the code!

@deroneriksson Good idea -- @MechCoder Can you (1) update the given example, (2) add the missing comma to that test, and (3) move the source code to the other location for this PR?  Then you could add the `Matrix` logic in a followup PR.

Also, you write great, clean Python code, @MechCoder! 👍
Add to whitelist.
LGTM.  Thanks, @sandeep-n!
Thanks @dusenberrymw @deroneriksson! I've moved it. We can address other stuff in followup PR's
Awesome, **LGTM**.  Thanks, @MechCoder!
Merged.  Thanks, @MechCoder!

I tested all possible combinations of matrix multiplies with tests.
Here are the scripts I used.

``` bash
#!/bin/bash

X1=(1 100 200)
X2=(100 200)
Y2=(1 100 200)
SX=(0.3 1.0)
SY=(0.3 1.0)

for x1 in ${X1[@]}
do
    for x2 in ${X2[@]}
    do
        y1=$x2
        for y2 in ${Y2[@]}
        do
            for sX in ${SX[@]}
            do
                for sY in ${SY[@]}
                do
                    echo "matmul_1 =>  x1=$x1, x2=$x2, y1=$y1, y2=$y2 sX=$sX, sY=$sY"
                    bin/systemml write_random.dml -nvargs x1=$x1 x2=$x2 y1=$y1 y2=$y2 sX=$sX sY=$sY Xf="X" Yf="Y" 2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml matmul_1.dml -nvargs Xf="X" Yf="Y" OUT="A" 2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml matmul_1.dml -gpu force=true -nvargs Xf="X" Yf="Y" OUT="B"  2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml threshold_test.dml -nvargs A="A" B="B"
                done
            done
        done
    done
done


X1=(1 100 200)
X2=(100 200)
Y1=(1 100 200)

for x1 in ${X1[@]}
do
    for x2 in ${X2[@]}
    do
        y2=$x2
        for y1 in ${Y1[@]}
        do
            for sX in ${SX[@]}
            do
                for sY in ${SY[@]}
                do
                    echo "matmul_2 =>  x1=$x1, x2=$x2, y1=$y1, y2=$y2 sX=$sX, sY=$sY"
                    bin/systemml write_random.dml -nvargs x1=$x1 x2=$x2 y1=$y1 y2=$y2 sX=$sX sY=$sY Xf="X" Yf="Y" 2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml matmul_2.dml -nvargs Xf="X" Yf="Y" OUT="A" 2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml matmul_2.dml -gpu force=true -nvargs Xf="X" Yf="Y" OUT="B"  2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml threshold_test.dml -nvargs A="A" B="B"
                done
            done
        done
    done
done



X1=(100 200)
X2=(1 100 200)
Y2=(1 100 200)

for x1 in ${X1[@]}
do
    y1=$x1
    for x2 in ${X2[@]}
    do
        for y2 in ${Y2[@]}
        do
            for sX in ${SX[@]}
            do
                for sY in ${SY[@]}
                do
                  echo "matmul_3 =>  x1=$x1, x2=$x2, y1=$y1, y2=$y2 sX=$sX, sY=$sY"
                    bin/systemml write_random.dml -nvargs x1=$x1 x2=$x2 y1=$y1 y2=$y2 sX=$sX sY=$sY Xf="X" Yf="Y" 2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml matmul_3.dml -nvargs Xf="X" Yf="Y" OUT="A"  2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml matmul_3.dml -gpu force=true -nvargs Xf="X" Yf="Y" OUT="B"  2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml threshold_test.dml -nvargs A="A" B="B"
                done
            done
        done
    done
done


X1=(1 100 200)
X2=(1 100 200)
Y1=(1 100 200)

for x1 in ${X1[@]}
do
    y2=$x1
    for x2 in ${X2[@]}
    do
        for y1 in ${Y1[@]}
        do
            for sX in ${SX[@]}
            do
                for sY in ${SY[@]}
                do
                  echo "matmul_4 =>  x1=$x1, x2=$x2, y1=$y1, y2=$y2 sX=$sX, sY=$sY"
                    bin/systemml write_random.dml -nvargs x1=$x1 x2=$x2 y1=$y1 y2=$y2 sX=$sX sY=$sY Xf="X" Yf="Y" 2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml matmul_4.dml -nvargs Xf="X" Yf="Y" OUT="A" 2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml matmul_4.dml -gpu force=true -nvargs Xf="X" Yf="Y" OUT="B"  2>/dev/null
                    bin/systemml threshold_test.dml -nvargs A="A" B="B"
                done
            done
        done
    done
done
```

The random matrices are written out using write_random.dml:

``` r
x1 = $x1 # rows in X
x2 = $x2 # cols in X
y1 = $y1 # rows in Y
y2 = $y2 # cols in Y
sX = $sX # sparsity for X
sY = $sY # sparsity for Y

X = rand(rows=x1, cols=x2, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=sX)
Y = rand(rows=y1, cols=y2, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=sY)

write(X, $Xf)
write(Y, $Yf)
```

Here are matmul_1,2,3,4:

``` r
X = read ($Xf)
Y = read ($Yf)

O = X %*% Y # <- matmul_1
O = X %*% t(Y) # <- matmul_2
O = t(X) %*% Y # <- matmul_3
O = t(X) %*% t(Y) # <- matmul_4

write (O, $OUT)
```

Matmul_1-4 are run with CPU and GPU and the results are compared:

``` r
A = read($A)
B = read($B)

compare = function (matrix[double] A, matrix[double] B) return (boolean out) {
  Ax = abs(A - B)
  T = Ax > 10e-6
  s = sum(T)
  out = s
}

x <- compare(A, B)
if (x){
  print (" MATRICES NOT MATCHED ")
}
```

All the tests passed.
@nakul02 Please change LOG.info to LOG.debug (or guard it with a flag) in LibMatrixCUDA.

@deroneriksson @dusenberrymw LGTM. Please feel free to merge.

@nakul02 This is good work  :+1: 

I have also tested this branch on Lenet for correctness (end-to-end):

``` bash
EPOCH=9.883720930232558 ITER=8500 Validation set accuracy (%): 99.1 step-size=0.006302494097246091
Number of executed GPU inst:    97877.
GPU mem tx time (alloc/dealloc/conversion/toDev/fromDev):       29.002/19.461/0.325/122.697/303.068 sec.
GPU mem tx count (alloc/dealloc/conversion/toDev/fromDev/evict):        294886/208883/17200/162609/97841/0.
```
Great @nakul02 and @niketanpansare! I'll go ahead and merge.
@MechCoder @dusenberrymw Cleanedup the implementation by not requiring start/eval.
Awesome! I'll check this out again later today.
Could you add a couple of tests? Thanks!
@MechCoder @dusenberrymw Is this replicating the functionality of https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/197/files#diff-0a0277e5cf166adf136c0d02b45427cfR54 ?
@MechCoder Thanks for the review!

@niketanpansare No, this just exposes the `Matrix` type that is present in the new Java `MLContext`.  Here, we return all of the correct types via a simple call to `get()` on a `MLResults` object, including returning the existing `Matrix` type from the new `MLContext` on the Java side.  On the Java side, the new `Matrix` type can already be used for future SystemML scripts, and contains methods for converting to other types, such as a Spark DataFrame.  We simply expose that functionality on the Python side here.  By only using a single `get()`, we reduce the complexity.

@dusenberrymw Cool. Since I have refactored the python code into package structure, either I can merge once ur PR is in or you can merge your code in the file https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/blob/python/src/main/python/SystemML/mlcontext.py once it is merged :)

@niketanpansare Awesome, let's go ahead and merge this PR in (once I add a few updates), and then we can merge your PR.  I want to go ahead and update some example code that relies on this PR to go along with a presentation from today.
@dusenberrymw sounds good. Please go ahead and merge when you are ready :+1:
@MechCoder Updated the PR to remove the `keepIndex` logic, update the comments, and add test cases.  All tests pass on Python 2 & 3.
Awesome. Feel free to merge. (Y)
Also updated JavaConversions asJavaList/seqAsJavaList and asScalaMap/MapAsScalaMaps calls.  Adding reflection to resolve differences to be addressed in separate PR.
Any updates? Want to seamlessly integrate into my spark ml pipeline, blocked by this.

For additional context, here's link to original JavaConversions commit:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/commit/955526046e1c1d4057a05e3646ed0f74972bebe1
and original scala profile commit:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/commit/f2ea8770ea79232e49bd57d9761de2c1f8823300

Hi @gweidner.

It turns out I was mistaken about the JavaConversions. Please see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-866. The seqAsJavaList and mapAsScalaMap are available in both 2.11 and 2.10, so the Java code shouldn't need any modifications.

Thank you Deron for catching!  I will revert the JavaConversion changes.
Initial tests passed:
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/597/

Tests in progress after restoring JavaConversions seqAsJavaList and mapAsScalaMap:
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/598/
LGTM. Thank you @gweidner
@dusenberrymw Added sorts before the drops
LGTM.
Thank you for reviewing @dusenberrymw! I will merge.
Thank you for reviewing!  All tests passed - I will merge.
@niketanpansare Sorry, is this still WIP? I can have a more detailed look tomorrow.
@MechCoder No, was merging @dusenberrymw's changes from yesterday.
@petro-rudenko Part of code in this PR was refactored (including bug-fixes) in the commit: https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/commit/f02f7c018b221384b5e02b13ac181122853f65ba
LGTM.
Overall this LGTM.   I noted a few other changes that we could go ahead and do too while we're at it.
@dusenberrymw Thank you for reviewing. PR has been merged.

@dusenberrymw 
Made the additional updates. I will merge. Thanks for reviewing!
Also, we could save the merging of `Matrix` and `matrix` for a future PR, and brainstorm some plans and infrastructure for it in the meantime.

Updated the code as per your comments. 

Also, I am fine with renaming the top-level package from SystemML to systemml. I kept package naming for backward compatibility. Let's get feedback from others before making this change.

I agree we should merge Matrix and matrix in seperate PR :+1:

@deroneriksson Since SystemML.py is likely going to be replace by a package structure once https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/197 is merged in, can you please hold off this PR ? Once the PR 197 is merged, we will have a seperate Python package artifact (as a tar file).
Updated the documentation: http://niketanpansare.github.io/incubator-systemml/beginners-guide-python.html

Unless there are major concerns, I think we should merge this PR now and create new PR for additional fixes. This is because any additional Python related changes (eg: improvements to MLContext, merging Matrix & matrix classes, release-related changes (SystemML v/s systemml, pip installer), examples, etc) are dependent on merging this PR.

For the **next set** of JIRAs/PRs, we should aim to complete the following **before** the upcoming official release:
1. Update the package from `SystemML` to `systemml`.  The entire `src/main/python` folder was added from scratch very recently with a new API that is not backwards compatible anyway, and the `mllearn` and `mlpipeline` components were also added recently after the previous release, we won't break anything, and will be more Pythonic in the process.
2. Remove the `MLResults.getDataFrame` and replace usages of `getDataFrame("matrixName")` with `get("matrixName").toDF()`.  This way, the API stays clean and simple for an end user, and will help with the upcoming merge of `Matrix` and `matrix`.  Keeping only `get()` makes it simple to get a mixture of datatypes out of a DML script at the same time. [See below example]
3. Remove the `MLResults.getNumPyArray`, add a `Matrix.toArray()` function on the Java and Python sides (returning a list in Python), add a `Matrix.toNumPyArray()` on the Python side, and replace usages of `getNumPyArray("matrixName")` with `get("matrixName").toNumPyArray()`.  @deroneriksson should be able to assist with adding this on the Java side.  Once again, this will keep the API clean, help the upcoming merge, and keeping only `get()` makes it simple to get a mixture of datatypes out of a DML script at the same time.
4.  Merge `Matrix` with `matrix`, keeping the later name.

Overall, I'm excited for the direction the Python API is moving! 👍 

Example of using `get()` for mixed datatypes (scalars, matrices, strings, etc):

``` python
from SystemML import MLContext, dml

rdd1 = sc.parallelize(["1.0,2.0", "3.0,4.0"])

sums = """
s1 = sum(m1)
m2 = m1 * 2
t = "whatever"
"""

ml = MLContext(sc)
script = dml(sums).input(m1=rdd1).out("s1", "m2", "t")
s1, m2, t = ml.execute(script).get("s1", "m2", "t")
s1, m2, t
```

Returns:

``` python
(10.0, Matrix, 'whatever')
```

Then, 

``` python
m2.toDF()
```

Returns

``` python
DataFrame[ID: double, C1: double, C2: double]
```

Additionally, the `Matrix` `m2` can be used directly as input in a subsequent script.

+1 for all 4 points. Two comments on "Update the package from SystemML to systemml": 
- Let's send an email on the dev mailing list to notify everyone of this change once the PR is created.
- The PR should also update the existing documentation and examples.
@dusenberrymw Updated mlcontext.py as per your suggestions. Please let me know if there are any more changes.
LGTM. Thanks @asurve for adding frame support in MLContext :+1:

This is valid for both spark 1.x and spark 2.  The original fix was from:
https://github.com/gweidner/incubator-systemml/commit/afcf6cb82daab40b36366b73aca79d2b615c7b23
Note getRowRDD refactored in https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/223.

Thanks Niketan for reviewing changes. 
Glen, I retrofitted these changes with my changes. 
Thanks
Arvind

@niketanpansare @dusenberrymw 
There is going to be another artifact added to the project devoted to Python? Shouldn't this be packaged with the regular jar and standalone tar.gz/zip?

@niketanpansare @dusenberrymw 
BTW I am fine with whatever approach you believe to be the best approach for Python users. If you think this PR should be closed w/o merging, that is fine. :-)

The shell script in the python package 'uploadToPyPI.sh' will create a tar.gz in dist/ directory. We can add that artifact into our release. Anyone can use command 'pip install ..tar.gz' and install SystemML.
Thank you @asurve for incorporating this into [SYSTEMML-568] including runtime.util.UtilFunctions refactoring.  Closing PR.

just for the future - it is important to keep files that are used in all backends free from Spark-specific imports; otherwise we get classnotfound errors in settings where spark libs are not in the classpath. Thanks.
Thank you @mboehm7 for the reminder as I just saw your commit.  Note this PR did not introduce/propose the refactoring into runtime.util.UtilFunctions.
It's probably a good idea to keep @lresende aware of the status of this to be sure that the release will follow Apache requirements.

I have created a JIRA: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-883

@lresende or @deroneriksson Do either one of you want to take it over ?

@niketanpansare I'm probably not a good choice for most Python tasks due to my lack of experience with it. :-)
Should I go ahead and close this PR?

No worries :) ...  I think we should not release the old SystemML.py (as it is deprecated) and only release the new Python package. Let's go ahead and close this PR.

@lresende commented on the JIRA that he will take a pass at this. If necessary, I too can help with it.
cc: @nakul02 @niketanpansare @dusenberrymw
I will close this PR and the accompanying JIRA.
thanks @MechCoder - one request; could you please make the input argument consistent with our command line flags, i.e., lower case?

This allows the following code to work from Spark Shell:

```
val addScript = dml("print(a + b)")
addScript.in(Map("a"->1,"b"->2))
```

rather than needing to cast (as previously required), as in the following:

```
addScript.in(Map("a"->1.asInstanceOf[AnyRef],"b"->2.asInstanceOf[AnyRef]))
```

@gweidner @mboehm7 @dusenberrymw @niketanpansare 
Unless there are objections, I will merge this tomorrow.

Were you referring to this (https://github.com/MechCoder/incubator-systemml/blob/59299d84c87fca085081fb3abc309c7d73a58244/src/main/python/SystemML/mlcontext.py#L327) or something else?

I have kept them consistent with what is on the Scala side. Let me know if you would still like to change those.

Great job @MechCoder!

I think @mboehm7 would like lowercase like line 135 of DMLScript.java:

```
+ "   -explain: <type> (optional) explain plan (hops, [runtime], recompile_hops, recompile_runtime)\n"
```
Whatever 'feels' right from the perspective of expectations of a Python developer is probably the best approach to use.
I can do that but it will be inconsistent with the enum `ExplainLevel` here (https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/mlcontext/MLContext.java#L120)

What is the motivation for removing these files after write? I would say that the crc files are perfectly expected when writing with hadoop io libs to local file system. However, I don't have a strong opinion here as the write with local file system never happens in practice except in our testsuite. But please ensure consistency between single-threaded and multi-threaded writers if this is brought in.

thanks for clarifying @deroneriksson - yes, I would prefer to have all warnings and errors consistent in lower case. It might be a good idea to simply call ExplainType.parseExplainType from all locations to have equivalent error handling. While you're at it, could you also change the parseExplainType implementation to valueof. Thanks.
LGTM.

Great feedback @dusenberrymw. I believe that StructType is made of StructFields and that StructField has a DataType that could probably be used. If there is some type of bottleneck experienced, I will update the code to examine the StructField values.

Thank you for reviewing.

I don't mind crc files in a distributed file system, but when matrices are written locally, the hidden crc files can become an annoyance. Since this is how I typically use SystemML (as a developer with little matrices rather than as a data scientist working on big data), this becomes an issue for me.

@mboehm7 What is the best way to test the multi-threaded writers (Writer*Parallel.java files)?

@MechCoder @mboehm7 @dusenberrymw 
Just to mention a thing about the MLContext design. The MLContext class contains an ExplainLevel enum that is basically a wrapper of the Explain class's ExplainType enum. The reason that ExplainLevel exists is so that it is in the same package as all the other main MLContext classes. Because of this, it allows a single import (import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._) to handle all MLContext classes, rather than needing to do multiple imports to use the MLContext API. This is very handy from a Scala perspective using SystemML from a Spark Shell.

The ExplainLevel values are uppercased as a Java enum convention. This allows Java/Scala developers to recognize these as 'constant' values. So, the uppercase format is useful when doing enums from Java or Scala, mostly as a convention.

However, for Python, if these are being treated as strings, maybe you could support both uppercase and lowercase strings to prevent case errors? That way you can match both the command-line flags and have symmetry with the Java/Scala.
Awesome, thanks for finding a fix for this, @deroneriksson.  LGTM.

+1 for allowing any case format, but encourage the lowercase format with the allowed types list.

+1 for only touching the `MLContext` API directly, rather than reaching down into the system.

Sure I'll add a comment to describe the reasoning.

Thanks for reviewing.

Hi @asurve. Adding Frame support to the MLContext API is a great addition to the project! I just finished reviewing the PR and made some notes below. Overall this is great.

LGTM. I think the best strategy is to merge and then maybe we can address some of the potential issues and improvements? Perhaps you could fix 2 and 5 below and then merge?

---

1) MLContext InternalProxy (lines 380:425)
Could you make a note to check with Matthias or Niketan to see if any updates need to be made here for frames?

2) MLContextConversionUtil line 373
dataFrameToFramexObject to dataFrameToFrameObject (as Mike mentioned).

3) MLContextConversionUtil
I think we will probably need to create something like a FrameMetadata class and a FrameFormat enum. MatrixMetadata is being used for Frame metadata, and since a Frame is a different entity, it should probably have its own associated metadata and format classes.

Does Frame internally use MatrixCharacteristics or does it need to have something like its own FrameCharacteristics class? If it uses something like MatrixCharacteristics, we could still have a FrameMetadata act as its wrapper at the API level.

4) MLContextConversionUtil
For frameObjectToListStringIJV and frameObjectToListStringCSV, since types such as Strings are allowed, there might need to be some fancier character escaping (or surrounding double quotes with quotes escaped inside) or something like that.

5) MLContextConversionUtil
Could getSparkContext and getJavaSparkContext methods be private scope? Either that or move them to MLContextUtil?

6) MLContextUtil
The convertInputType takes a boolean flag but I've tried to avoid boolean flags in the API. Perhaps we can solve this using a FrameMetadata class in the future.

7) MLResults
We might want to create a Frame wrapper class similar to the Matrix wrapper class. We could have MLResults getFrame() method return a Frame object, similar to the getMatrix() method that returns a Matrix object.

8) MLResults
We need to be careful with methods such as the ones that take in delimiter strings. If we have multiple values like this and we don't encapsulate them, the API potentially becomes more difficult to use. It is a nice feature to have though.

10) Script
The inputVariablesType map and the boolean flag on the in() method are functional but I think a cleaner option may be to have classes/enums for Frame, FrameMetadata, and FrameFormat.

11) MLContextTest
Since the additional tests all concern frame tests and the tests are coded in a different format than all the existing tests, perhaps they could be moved to a new MLContextFrameTest class?

cc @dusenberrymw @bertholdreinwald @frreiss
Looks like writing a big matrix triggers the multi-threaded write.
yes, >128MB (one partition) but note that the parallel writers do not overwrite "writeMatrixToHDFS" which makes this method a good candidate to add it once for both.
@mboehm7 Thank you for the information.

good point @deroneriksson - I'm not in favor of this redundancy but I understand your reasoning behind it. Let's leave the MLContext ExplainLevel for now but let's ensure consistency across all entry points for the following aspects: (1) consistency of defaults (explain=true it's 'runtime' not 'hops'), (2) string specification in lower case, (3) consistent warning/error messages. Thanks.

ad 3) The meta data is by design shared across frame and matrix. The same applies to the input/output formats. Please keep the meta data and formats orthogonal to the data type. Thanks.

ad 8) You can use CSVFileFormatProperties (subclass of FileFormatProperties) which already encapsulates parameters such header, delimiter, fill, and fillvalue.

in addition: Please be more careful when constructing the filenames for matrix and frame objects. Make sure that the process_id (IP and process id which makes it unique across the cluster) is appended as the suffix to the scratch_space already and use the appropriate sequence ids (NOT time) as done in Lops.DAG. Otherwise there is a risk that multiple users running on the same cluster affect each other.

@mboehm7 At some point when you have time, I'd really appreciate it if you could review the references to MLContextUtil.scratchSpace() in MLContextConversionUtil and make corrections as needed for the scratch space paths.
cc @deroneriksson, @niketanpansare, @MechCoder

Great! LGTM. Removing the redundant methods from the Java side helps simplify the API. Also, input/output on the Python side (vs input/out) makes its usage more intuitive.

cc @bertholdreinwald
sure - once I'm back, I'll create some abstractions which can be used by all APIs as well as related tests.

@mboehm7 I added some additional code to delete the .crc files for the multipart files when written to the local file system. Tested this on OSX with large and small matrices for csv, ijv, mm, and binary.

I believe this PR can be closed now.
@asurve If you amend the commit message with "Closes #225", when you push to apache master, GitHub will automatically close the PR for you.
